quote: Captain's log, stardate 42609.1.   In response to a desperate plea   for aid by my old friend, Captain   Donald Varley of the USS Yamato,   I am running a grave risk and   taking the Enterprise into the   Neutral Zone.

This rendezvous is necessitated   by dangerous malfunctions which   are plaguing our sister ship.   Perhaps with both crews working   together we will be able to   eliminate the problem -- before   we are detected by the Romulans.
Mister Crusher -- how long to   rendezvous?
Four minutes, thirty-three   seconds, sir.
Status of download, Mister Data?
Entire Yamato log will be in our   computer by rendezvous.
Have you nailed down our little   hiccup yet?
Sir?
The odd reading.
No. It might be due to the   problems currently being   experienced by the Yamato.
Trouble, Number One?
I'm not sure, sir.       We are alone out here?
Yes, sir. There are no other   vessels in the area except the   Yamato.       Which is coming into viewer range   now.
Transmission from the Yamato,   Captain -- on visual.
Donald, what's a nice Starfleet   Captain like you doing in a place   like this?

It's good to see you, Jean-Luc,   despite your antique humor. I   only hope your people can help   us. The malfunctions are becoming   serious. We lost an engineering   team when the computer shut down   the forcefield in an open shuttle   bay. Eighteen people.
And no idea what's causing these   problems?

None. They are affecting every   system simultaneously. It's like   the ship has suddenly decided to   fall apart.       It's beginning to make me think   we should have run these Galaxy   Class ships across a few more   drawing boards before we built   one.
Are you suggesting it's a design   flaw?
I don't know. I'm grasping at   straws here. All I know is that   we've got to get it fixed, and   before I lose more than an   engineering team.
Do you wish to evacuate   non-essential personnel to the   Enterprise?
No... that would be premature.
Donald, we'll get our teams to   work. I'm sure neither of us   feels too comfortable sitting   around the Neutral Zone.

I know what you're thinking, what   the hell am I doing here? Well,   I had heard rumors about a couple   of archaeological digs that   started making the Iconians sound   a lot less like legend. I did   a little investigating, and I   located their homeworld.
In the Neutral Zone.
In the Neutral Zone.
Don, this was quite a risk to   run just to satisfy an   archaeological curiosity.
No, the risk would be in allowing   the Romulans to locate Iconia.
Fortunately, I got there first.   It's a virtually dead planet, but   enough of the technology remains   to give the Romulans an edge if   they were ever to find it.
Don, your transmission is breaking   up.       Clean that up.
Sir, there is an energy build-up   in the Yamato's engineering   section.
Yamato, this is the Enterprise,   come in Yamato.
Magnetic seals in the antimatter   chamber decaying!
Captain. Don!
Shields up!
Sir!
scene: 6    INT. MAIN BRIDGE AND VIEWSCREEN - VARIOUS ANGLES

quote: Sensors indicate no life readings   from the Yamato's saucer section.
scene: 6    INT. MAIN BRIDGE AND VIEWSCREEN - VARIOUS ANGLES

quote: (looks up from his     instruments)   Captain! Another vessel coming   into sensor range.       It is Romulan.
scene: 6    INT. MAIN BRIDGE AND VIEWSCREEN - VARIOUS ANGLES

quote: Captain's log, supplemental. The   Yamato's entire crew and their   families, more than a thousand   people, have been lost.
Circumstances, unfortunately,   permit us no pause for grief.
No response from the Romulan   vessel.
Arm phasers and prepare to lock   on target.
Did they attack the Yamato?
Unknown, sir.
All their weapons systems have   been fully activated. Still no   response.
(upward glance; then,     sternly)   Romulan vessel, this is Captain   Picard of the USS Enterprise.   Explain your illegal presence in   the Neutral Zone --
Explain yours!
Are you responsible for the   destruction of the Yamato?
No. And believe me, Captain, had   we chosen to exercise our right   to defend the Neutral Zone, we   would not have stopped with one   starship. You will leave at   once.
(looking to his bridge     crew)   Comments?
She is extremely anxious --
Understandable if she just   destroyed a Federation starship.
Your scan was inconclusive. We   can't be sure of what happened   to the Yamato.
Our presence in the Neutral Zone   is provocative. It could force   her to respond.
Open com. We will comply when   we have determined the cause of   the Yamato's destruction. And   when we are fully satisfied that   you were not responsible. Picard   out.
They are engaging their cloaking   device.
Good. They can't fire when   they're cloaked.
Unless they have overcome that   deficiency. The Yamato was   destroyed while they were cloaked.
Forget the Romulans. I want to   know what happened to the Yamato.   Number One, assemble the staff   for a conference in one hour.   And I want answers.
Aye, sir.
Sensor recordings reveal that what   we witnessed was an uncontrolled   and catastrophic matter/antimatter   mix. The magnetic seals between   the chambers collapsed --
That's not possible.
Yes, sir, it is, but a highly   improbable series of events has   to take place before such an   occurrence can result.
Explain.
In the event of a breach of seal   integrity there is an emergency   release system which dumps the   antimatter.
Apparently such a dump began, was   then halted, and the containment   seals were dropped. There was   still sufficient antimatter   present to lead to the result we   observed.
Then there is no evidence that   a weapon was used?
I'm sorry I'm late. I was with   the children. They have been   deeply affected by the Yamato's   destruction.
Mister Data.
Evidence of a weapon? No, sir,   none.
However it happened, the Yamato   did it to herself.
Theorize. What do you think   caused this catastrophic   malfunction?
I think Captain Varley may have   been correct. There could be   a design flaw.
In a Galaxy Class starship?
Yes, sir. It's the most   complicated piece of machinery   ever built. Something could have   been overlooked.
Knowing where the flaw is located,   do you think you can isolate and   solve the problem?
We're working on it now.
Pull any and all personnel who   might be useful to your task.
If we have established that the   Romulans were not responsible for   the destruction of the Yamato,   would it not be prudent for us   to withdraw?
If this is a design flaw, we   better stay where we are and   give Geordi time to work. Or   what happened to the Yamato   could happen to us.
Computer, access Captain Donald   Varley's personal log. Search   parameter, locate entries   containing the words Romulan and   Iconia.
Working.

Personal log. It was kind of   Doctor Ramsey to allow me to carry   away my own little piece of legend   from the archaeological dig on   Denius Three. My engineers have   examined it, but are completely baffled   by the technology. What was its   purpose? I'm like a caveman   confronted by a tricorder. I'm   certain this device is Iconian.   But how far had it travelled   before it was abandoned on an   alien world?

Personal log. A galactic Rosetta   stone. The starfield shown on   the artifact was unintelligible   until I took into account two   hundred millenia of stellar   drift. After that it was easy   to pinpoint Iconia.

My first officer is questioning   the wisdom of my order to   violate the Neutral Zone, but   I am convinced I have taken the   only proper course. Should this   advanced technology fall into   the hands of the Romulans, we   might as well dock our ships   and defend ourselves with sticks.
Personal log. We've been spotted   by a Romulan cruiser, but after   playing hide and seek through   several solar systems, I think   I've managed to elude them.
The Iconian probe scan -- was it   an attempt at communication? If   only I knew what we were dealing   with here.

Personal log. I am unable to send   an away team to the surface of   Iconia, nor can I scan the energy   source on the planet because of   these maddening system failures.   It is infuriating to be stopped   at the threshold of a dream by   one's own ship. We are leaving   orbit to rendezvous with Picard.   If his people can't help us repair   the Yamato, I must convince him   to continue this exploration.   The future well being of the   Federation may depend upon it.
No further entries conforming to   search parameters.
Mister Data, there is a reference   in Captain Varley's personal log   to a probe which scanned the   Yamato.
Yes, sir. We have a visual   record.
Put it on Main Viewer.
What the devil is that?
Have you ever seen anything like   that before?
No, sir, but it appears to be   a scanner. Possibly a   transmitter.
Transmitting what?
Unknown, sir.
Engineering.
La Forge.
Progress on your matter/antimatter   scan?
Everything continues to check   out. I'm starting an analysis   of the magnetic coils.
Data, when the Yamato was probed,   where was she?
In orbit around a planet at   coordinates two two seven mark   three five nine.
Estimated time of arrival at warp   factor eight?
Twelve hours, sixteen minutes.
Sir, that would put us   substantially closer to the   Romulan side of the Neutral Zone.
It can't be helped. Ensign   Crusher, lay in a course. Warp   factor eight.
We are going to assume the   Yamato's mission.
And risk a war?
If that's what it takes to get   some answers.
Come.
Sir, may I talk to you for a   minute?
Yes.
It's about the Iconians, sir.   I'd always heard that they were   just a myth.

China was thought to be only a   myth until Marco Polo travelled   there. No, the Iconians were   real. We know that three   systems in this sector have a   number of cultural similarities.   Similarities which can be   explained only if there had been   a single unifying force.
The Iconians colonized those   worlds?
Probably conquered.
So they were warlike?
Perhaps. Ancient texts refer   to them as the Demons of Air and   Darkness, but that could have   so many different interpretations.
Air and darkness?
Legend has it that they travelled   without the benefit of spaceships.   Merely appearing from thin air   on distant planets.
That sounds like magic.
Wouldn't we seem magical to a   stone-age people?
(responding to Picard's     enthusiasm and echoing     it)   How did you find out about all   this?
Archaeology has been a hobby since   my Academy days. But why don't   we talk about what really brought   you here?
I can't stop thinking about the   Yamato. All those people -- dead.   I just don't know how you do it.   You, Commander Riker, Geordi, you   all handle it so easily.
Easily. No, not easily.
Darjeeling tea, hot.   We handle it because we are   trained to, as you will be. But   if the time ever comes when the   death of even a single individual   fails to move us --
That should not have happened.
Captain's log, supplemental. As   happened with her sister, the   Enterprise is being plagued by   a series of system failures.
So far they are random, but   perhaps early symptoms of what   happened to the Yamato.
La Forge!
Lieutenant, are you making any   progress toward a solution to our   problems?
A solution, no sir, but I can   eliminate one worry. It is not   a design flaw. I've been   reviewing the Yamato's log, and   I think maybe that alien probe   had something to do with her   problems.
How?
I'd need to see the thing.
If it was the probe, that explains   the Yamato; but how do you account   for the difficulties the   Enterprise is experiencing?
I can't.
Are our problems likely to attain   the seriousness experienced by   the Yamato?
If you want speculation, yes sir,   I think they are. I need time.
Lieutenant, time is the one   thing which we do not have in   abundance.
Scanning.
Mister Data.
No life-form readings.
All major cities have been   heavily damaged, and the pattern   of destruction is consistent   with large-scale orbital   bombardment.
How long ago?
Approximately two hundred   thousand years.
There is an energy source in the   mountains of the smaller   continent.
Magnify.
Is this Iconia?
Donald Varley died believing that   it was.
Captain! Projectile launched from   the planet's surface!
Its size and composition match   the probe which scanned the   Yamato.
Shields up. Ready the tractor   beam. Lieutenant La Forge, I'm   about to assist you in your   research. A probe has been   launched from Iconia. I intend   to capture it.
No, sir, wait!
Captain! Captain!       Damn!
Bridge!
Emergency stop!
Emergency stop! Stop dammit!
Tractor beam ready, sir.
scene: 25   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE

quote: Prepare to lower shields,   Mister Crusher.
scene: 25   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE

quote: Geordi, are you --
scene: 25   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE

quote: Destroy it, sir, quickly!
scene: 25   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE

quote: Worf, target phasers!
scene: 25   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE

quote: Phasers locked on target.
scene: 25   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE

quote: Fire!
scene: 25   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE

quote: (continuing; cool as     ice)   Mister La Forge, are you all right?
scene: 25   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE

quote: Yes, sir, and thank you for   trusting me. If that thing had   managed to scan us, we would have   had no hope of saving the   Enterprise.
scene: 25   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON THE PROBE

quote: That probe was a transmitter   sending an alien computer program.   The same program that is currently   aboard the Enterprise and trying   to rewrite our software in its   own image. We have two   completely incompatible computer   systems trying to interact.
So that's why the ship's   instruments have become so   erratic.
Yes.
What can you do?
Not very much. The Iconian   program is so sophisticated I   don't think I'll ever understand   it.

Consider, Captain, this program   has entered an alien data base   -- ours -- and in less than seven   hours it has managed to not only   learn our system, but has also   begun to reprogram our computer.
So the earlier probe was   responsible for the Yamato's   destruction.
Only insofar as the probe   transmitted the program.
But we weren't scanned by the   probe. So how did this thing   get aboard the Enterprise?
We downloaded the Yamato log, and   contained in the log was the   program.
So why haven't we suffered their   fate?

The program affected all systems   on the Yamato simultaneously.   But with us, the program was   deposited in a specific section   of our mainframe. It's having   to work its way out from that   location. That gives us a little   breathing space.
Not much. Reports of injuries   are mounting.
Doctor Pulaski is unwilling to   trust the turbolifts. She is   sending medical teams through the   access tunnels.

Sir, the Enterprise computer   system is a lot like our bodies   with a voluntary and involuntary   system. Probably ninety percent   of what happens on this ship is   done automatically, completely   beyond our control. We're sitting   on a bomb that could go any second   -- or never.
Can you stop this thing?
I'll give it my best shot.

The biobeds aren't working.   The ship's falling apart and   you're wasting my time about   biobeds? I've got thirty-five   emergency calls scattered across   twelve decks and my trauma teams   are being run ragged trying to   respond.    (almost to herself,     flinging up her hands)   Biobeds!
Doctor Pulaski.
What?
I've got a problem here.
The knitter isn't working.
Use a splint.
Splint. It's a very ancient   concept -- two flat pieces of wood   or plastic, a bandage. The broken   limb is kept immobile.
That's crazy, that's not   practicing medicine.
Oh yes it is. A time-honored way   of practicing medicine -- by   using your head and your heart   and your hands. So jump to it.
Dammit!
Try a bypass on the shield control   interface.
No go. Let me see if I can   directly access the master   program.
What happened?
Any answer would be mere   speculation. This is just another   example of how our actions have   random results.
Thank you, Data, I noticed.
Life support has failed on Decks   Seven and Thirteen.
Suppose this thing manages to   rewrite our entire system? It's   so far beyond us that we don't   have a hope of understanding it,   much less controlling it. Our   ignorance could kill us.
We may never reach that point.   A variation of what happened to   the Yamato may destroy us first.
So we just sit here while the ship   disintegrates around us?
The probe was launched from   Iconia, probably by an automated   system. There may be records   near the launch site which   could help us find a solution.
I'll form an away team.
I will lead it.
You will lead it?
Yes.
We've had this discussion a   hundred times before.
Will, ever since I was a cadet   I've studied the Iconians. I have   to be the one to go.
The Enterprise is yours.
For as long as she lasts.
I've got a fix on the energy   source, and for the moment this   baby...    (points to the     transporter console)   ... is working, but that could   change in an instant.
We're aware of the risks.   Energize.
Transport complete.
Stay sharp, Mister O'Brien, I want   to be able to pull them out at   a moment's notice.
Commander, Romulan vessel!
Open hailing frequencies.
They're arming photon torpedoes!
Shields up! Go to Red Alert!
Shields not responding.
They are preparing to fire photon   torpedoes!
Ensign Crusher, we need those   shields!
I'm trying, sir!
Firing.
What happened?
Instead of firing they suddenly   disarmed and cancelled.
Fate protects fools, little   children and ships called   Enterprise.       Lock phasers on the Romulan, but   hold your fire.
Sir, the shields are up.
Impeccable timing.
Uh, shields are back down.
Phaser banks are down.
The shields are back up.
In another time and another place   this could be funny.
Status of the torpedo banks?
They're down too.
In case it should become necessary   to fight, do you suppose you could   find me some rocks to throw at   them?
Sir, the Romulan torpedoes are   continuing to arm and disarm.
Maybe their attempt to fire   was not intentional.       Open hailing frequencies.
Open.
Romulan vessel, this is Commander   William Riker, first officer of   the USS Enterprise. Why did you   attempt to fire on us?
This is Sub-Commander Taris of   the Haakona. Why have you   penetrated deeper into the   Neutral Zone?
Why are you still here?
I have claimed this planet for   the Romulan Empire.
This is the Neutral Zone. Nobody   can claim anything.
You will withdraw or I will be   forced to destroy your ship and   your away team.
What the hell?
This is your final warning, I   will not --
Having a little trouble with your   systems, Commander? Maybe we   could consider postponing the war   until we solve our more immediate   problem?
You're stalling for time.
Sir, another probe launched from   the planet, heading for the   Romulan.
Have we got our phasers back?
No, sir.
Taris, if you've got phaser   capability, you better use it now!
What?
Destroy that probe!
And not even a thank you.
Sub-Commander Taris is deeply   frustrated, probably because her   ship is as crippled as the   Enterprise.
Why would the Romulans be having   problems? They haven't been   probed.
They must have tapped into the   Yamato log. Taris got a whole   lot more than she bargained for.
Commander, sensors indicate the   Romulans are attempting to   transport a team.       They lost them, complete   molecular break-up.
So the captain is safe for the   moment.
Safe from the Romulans.       Maintain Red Alert, and try to   keep those shields up just in case   Taris feels she has to act on her   threat.
(slewing around in his     chair)   Sir, what about the away team?   With our shields up we can't beam   them back.
Enterprise. Come in Enterprise.   Still no response, sir.
Keep trying them. Communication   is going to be erratic.
I do not want to become a   permanent resident of this   planet.
Nor do I, Mister Worf.
Scans indicate no other life-forms   on the planet.
I would not expect any. Judging   from the severity of bombardment,   I doubt any Iconians survived.
Well, Mister Data, let us see if we   can make sense of this.
Aye, sir.
This is very reminiscent of   Dinasian.
Yes, sir. There are also   similarities to Dewan and Iccobar.
Is it possible that they are all   branches of a language family   beginning with Iconian?
Yes.
Run a comparison between simple,   basic words in Dinasian, Dewan   and Iccobar. Let's see if we   can't reconstruct a common root   language.
Accessing.
You're jumpy.
The tension on the ship is very   high.
What's your recommendation?
Give everyone something else to   think about, some place to focus   their attention.
All right, let's consider   evacuation.
To the planet?
It's risky with Taris sitting   out there -- it's probably   impossible to pull off, but it   will give everyone something   to do. You go and start   organizing it.
But you will need me if you   have to negotiate with Taris   again.
I'll manage. Right now   they're more important.

Captain, your original hypothesis   was correct. Iconian is the   parent tongue for a language   family consisting of Dewan,   Iccobar and Dinasian. I have   constructed a basic working   understanding through a comparison   of common root words such as   mother, father, food, death,   child, home, tribe, pain, love,   mine, yours, ours --
Data, Data, Data -- the point.
You do understand that my   interpretation of the symbols will   not be exact?
Yes, let's get on with it.
(pointing to a set of     symbols)   This would appear to be the manual   override.
That was not manual override.
Demons of Air and Darkness,   indeed.
What is that?
A gateway.
The scenes could be holographic   images.
Data, that was very foolish.
But we have established it is   not a holograph. If I step   through and investigate, we would   determine whether it is truly a   gateway.
No, Data. You might not be able   to get back, and I can't risk   losing you.
If it's not illusion, this gate   would seem to take you beyond the   confines of this planet.
Is this how the Iconians   travelled? Stepping across light   years as easily as we would cross   a room? Those worlds might be   in distant sectors of our galaxy.
(continuing; almost to     himself)   This is what Varley feared. What   he lost his life for.
Sir?
The Romulans could turn this   technology into a weapon.
Like the Iconians did.
No, I believe that to be   incorrect. Captain, there is   nothing in this room to indicate   it was used as a military command   center. It is much more akin to   a transporter room.
But the probe was hostile.
We can't make that assumption.   The probe's effect on the Yamato   was devastating, but I suspect   that was by accident rather than   design.
We do know that the Iconians were   conquerors.
Do we? The little we know was   passed down by the descendants   of the people who attacked this   world. I'm beginning to think   the Iconians may have been the   victims of some very bad press.
Sir?

There's an unfortunate tendency   in most cultures to fear what they   don't understand. It is possible   that their enemies, when confronted   with this technology, were driven   to attack the Iconians out of   fear.
Sir!
Was that really the Enterprise?

I believe that it was. Gentlemen,   we have a way home.       I think the Iconians might have   outfoxed their enemies. Perhaps   they didn't all die in the   bombardment; some may have passed   through this.
Sir, there is a vast underground   power source which is controlled   by this console.
My triggering of the gateway has   caused a dramatic upsurge in power   levels.       Ah, I have access.
Sir, the Enterprise again.
Time the rotation.
Data, respond.
Captain.
Are you all right?
No, I am damaged.
How bad is it?
The Iconian program is attempting   a rewrite of my basic software.   Physical manifestations --
Sir, without him we have no hope   of deciphering the program.
How long until the Enterprise   reappears?
Six minutes if the cycle holds.
Stand ready, Mister Worf, and go   through with Data. Geordi can   learn from him. Maybe help him.
Sir, we have not yet established   that that...       ... is truly a gateway.
This will be the test.
Aye, sir.
Data, give me your tricorder.
Sir, what is your present   location?
I'm right in front of you... Data,   what is it?
Please, take the tricorder. I   am unable to sufficiently pinpoint   your location to be able to hand   it to you.
You're blind.
Yes, sir.
(handing the tricorder     to Worf)   Destroy this.
But, sir, it contains the record   of all that we have discovered   here.
And that is precisely why it must   be destroyed. Time?
Three minutes.
I am running out of time. We   all are.
This room and the technology   contained in it must be destroyed.   It cannot be allowed to fall into   Romulan hands.
I understand...
How! How do I do it? How can   I destroy everything? Control   room, the probes? All of it.
The... power... source.
I detonate it?
Yes.
How? What do I do?
The... probes.
Probes... the probes. Launch?   Do I launch the probes?
What's that going to do? Nothing.
Doors.
Doors?
Perhaps the probes are in a   launch bay.
The doors will open automatically   when the launch begins. I'd have   to override.
Yes.
The power source! The backwash   from the rockets will spill into   the main power grids and cause   an overload.
Cor... rect.
Which control keys? Damn, I   forgot you can't see.
Help.
Describe.
We're directly opposite the   gateway. There is a rectangular   screen.
Left... one meter.
Triangular screen. The lights   directly above are solid amber.   To the left red --
Cor... rect. Key... blue,   amber... amber... red.
That's the launch sequence?
How do I override the doors?
Blue, blue, blue.

I hope you're not stuttering.       I don't know how long a delay   there will be between the launch   and the detonation. I'll hold   off keying the launch sequence   until you're through the gate.   How long until the Enterprise   returns?
Almost time, sir. Captain, you   will be killed.
I'll go through the gate.
But where will you end up?
Any place is going to be better   than this room. Worf, I'm   depending on you. Get Data back   to the Enterprise. He may be   their last hope.
Worf! What happened? Where's   the captain?
We must take Data to Engineering.
I don't know how to help him.   But comparing recorded norms for   Data to the current readings, it's   clear that all his functions are   going crazy. If we had an expert   -- Maddox, or somebody --
He's gone.
Kandar se. Kandar ere.
Data!
What the hell?
Ah, I have access.
The self-correcting mechanism --
Captain? Captain?
It's constantly kicking in to make   minute adjustments in the   positronic brain.
This is the Enterprise. How did   I get here?
He cleared the Iconian program   from his own system. How?
Iconia? I was on Iconia. Now   I am on the Enterprise.
Geordi, this is critical. How?

Let me think for a second. There   was an incompatible program   running through Data's system, so   the mechanism started searching   for a way to keep him alive. The   solution must have been a shutdown   and a total wipe of all affected   memory.
Query. What have I forgotten?
One question. Can we do the same   thing with the Enterprise?

I don't see why not... but it will   have to be a complete shutdown.   We turn her off, effect a wipe   of the Yamato log and every   subsequent event since we   downloaded it. I'll then reload   all the ship's programs from the   protected archives in the main   core.
Geordi, a shutdown means that the   shields are going to be coming   down too, and we're hanging nose   to nose with a Romulan battle   cruiser.
Hey, Commander, whether it's   Romulan phasers or our own   warp engines we're just as dead.
Make it so.
Can I help?
Kandar more, kandar sete, kandar   ne.
All systems functioning.
Lock on the captain and bring him   back.
Scanning, sir. Got him.
Kandar qetar, Kandar jet, kandar   piqe, kandar...
Setha-tri par trukatha.
I've lost him!
Damn it!
Got him! Sir! He's on the   Romulan ship.
How the hell... never mind.   Energize!
You did this.
Setha-ki par trukatha.
Did what?
Activated the auto-destruct. I   at least have the satisfaction   that you will die with us.
Setha-mille par trukatha.
(feeling the effects     of the transporter     kicking in)   Not I think, today, Commander.
Bridge.
Yes, sir.
Get us out of here. The Romulan   ship is set for auto-destruct and   they can't deactivate it.
Wait, sir.       Open a hailing frequency.
Open, sir.
Commander Taris, prepare to   receive a transmission from our   chief engineer. He'll instruct   you on how to purge your system.
Commander, your transmission has   been received and acknowledged.
Now, Mister Data, warp speed please   -- just in case Taris's engineer   is not as efficient as Lieutenant   La Forge.
Yes, sir.       Captain, sensors picking up a   large explosion on the surface   of Iconia. It is equivalent to   a force twelve hydrogen explosion.   Blast radius is nine hundred   kilometers.

The dust particles entering the   stratosphere will take an   estimated seven months to fall   back to the surface. The   diminution in sunlight will have   the effect of lowering average   daily surface temperatures on   Iconia by fifteen degrees   Celsius.
I see Data's back to normal.
With a little touch of amnesia.
It seems that everything is back   to normal. Well done, Commander.
Thank you, sir.
